Crimes.Crime_Name: Breach of Navigation and Vessel Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Liability for cutting submarine cable and right to limit liability
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Notices published by Telus, Vallée's knowledge and actions
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Defendants held liable for $980,433.54 plus interest
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On claimant (Telus) to prove negligence and damages
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Vallée's mistaken belief about cable abandonment assessed as unreasonable
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Liability arises from breach of duty of care; limitation denied for intentional/reckless acts
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness and correctness in application of maritime conventions
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Analysis of negligence, contributory negligence, and insurance coverage
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Damage caused by unauthorized cutting of active submarine cable
Crimes.Review_Standard: De novo for questions of law, reasonableness for factual findings
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Fair hearing provided with full examination of evidence
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Published notices, use of electric saw, failure to verify status
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Marine Liability Act, international maritime conventions
Crimes.Applicant_Challenge: Establishing liability and preventing limitation of liability
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed belief that cable was abandoned
Crimes.Outcome: Damages awarded, no right to limit liability
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Monetary compensation for repair and service interruption
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Marine Liability Act, Article 4 of 1976 Limitation Convention
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Telus as owner/operator of the cable
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Allegation of reckless and intentional conduct
Crimes.Applicable_Process: Civil litigation under federal maritime jurisdiction
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Duty of care in navigation; prohibition on damaging submarine cables

Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Full liability imposed, right to limit liability denied

Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Defendant’s belief in abandonment deemed unreasonable
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Wilful misconduct negates right to limit liability under Article 4
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness for legal interpretation, reasonableness for facts
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Limitation of liability and insurance denial due to misconduct
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Intentional destruction of valuable infrastructure causing significant financial loss
Crimes.Review_Standard: Mixed: correctness for legal conclusions, deference to factual findings
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Due process followed in assessing intent and liability
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Use of electric saw, disregard of published notices, repetition of act
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Criminal Code (wilful mischief), Marine Liability Act
Crimes.Applicant_Challenge: Proving intentionality and exclusion from liability cap
Crimes.Legal_Rule_Source: Article 4, 1976 Limitation Convention; Marine Liability Act
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Asserted honest but mistaken belief the cable was abandoned
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Direct and circumstantial evidence, documentary notices
Crimes.Outcome: Full damages awarded; limitation defense rejected
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Recovery of repair costs and lost revenue
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 427 of Criminal Code (wilful mischief), Marine Liability Act
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Private corporation (Telus) seeking redress for property damage
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Alleged intentional and reckless damage to protected infrastructure
Crimes.Applicable_Process: Civil action incorporating elements of statutory and common law liability
Crimes.Governing_Rule: No limitation of liability where loss results from personal act or omission done with intent or recklessness
